page.title: 01INTRODUCTION
page.content: Our Domesday area stretches from Butser Hill, north to Park Hill and from the hamlet of Ramsdean, west to the village of East Meon, which was mentioned in the Domesday Book. This is a rural area set amongst the rolling chalk hills of the western end of the South Downs. Although dry valleys are common, our area contains a river - the River Meon, which rises in the south-west corner of the area. This area has probably been settled continuously for 5000 years; there is evidence of Neolithic Man on both Butser and Barrow Hills, and there is a tradition of Roman settlement. Intensive farming now prevails. Much downland pasture has been ploughed for rape and wheat crops,although sheep are grazed on steeper slopes. Butser Hill has been preserved within the Queen Elizabeth Country Park.
